awd_titl_txt: Age differences in when - not whether - sensory regions are recruited during memory retrieval
awd_abstract_narration:
With the population aging and older adults staying in the workforce longer, the need to understand the memory changes that occur with aging is more urgent than ever. Although multiple theories have been proposed to explain age-related changes occurring in the lab, there is reason to believe that some laboratory assessments of memory may overestimate age-related deficits. Such overestimations can cause researchers and practitioners to propose and implement ineffective support strategies and solutions for older adults. The proposed research examines the possibility that researchers have been systematically misinterpreting age-related changes in memory by not giving older adults enough time to complete the task. The research looks at individual differences across individuals, as well as at changes within an individual over time, to test multiple competing theories that have been proposed to explain these changes. The outcomes of this research will improve the likelihood of eventual translational impact of laboratory studies, opening the possibility for new types of strategies that older adults can be taught to maximize their chance of memory success. This project will also encourage communication of a realistic and positive portrayal of memory changes with aging to individuals who will benefit the most from this knowledge - older adults and individuals in the community who regularly engage with and teach older adults - using social media and in-person events. 

Memory complaints are common among older adults, and even healthy aging is associated with significant alterations in memory performance across tasks and domains. A prevailing view in the cognitive aging literature is that such changes in older adults are related to ineffective recruitment of sensory regions due to a global sensory deficit. The prominent piece of evidence in support of this theory from the cognitive neuroscience literature has been the prevalence of age-related decreases in posterior sensory recruitment across cognitive domains. Recent research has drawn the generality of this conclusion into question by revealing that age differences in sensory recruitment during memory tasks can reflect shifts in when sensory processes are engaged during retrieval rather than in whether they are engaged. In other words, aging may not strip away older adults' ability to engage sensory processes in the service of memory; but it may prevent them from engaging the processes in the same, fast manner as young adults. The proposed research brings this new possibility into focus, honing in on mechanisms that lead to temporal shifts in the recruitment of sensory regions and the behavioral consequences of these shifts. This research examines possible alternatives to the standard sensory deficit hypothesis, using cross-sectional and longitudinal designs. To accomplish the research aims, this proposal brings together a team of researchers who have a history of collaboration and complementary expertise in the cognitive neuroscience of aging and memory, structural MRI analysis, physiological age-related neural changes, and quantitative methods.

por.por_cntn:
Healthy aging is associated with a number of cognitive changes, including decreases in memory performance. Research into the way that brain regions support memory have also revealed age-related changes to neural recruitment, such as the commonly reported shift from reliance on regions in the back of the brain that support sensory processing to those in the front of the brain that support more conceptual thinking. This pattern has led researchers to hypothesize that older adults’ memory may be impaired, in part, due to a difficulty in relying on sensory processing during memory retrieval. However, it was recently shown that, in some cases, older adults can rely on these regions during the later part of an elongated retrieval trial. If so, aging may not exhibit an overall deficit in sensory processing, but rather a delay in this processing. The current project examined the circumstances under which older adults were able to rely on sensory processing during retrieval, focusing on potential supports that may be put in place for future tasks and everyday remembering.

One hundred and one participants from across the adult lifespan (ages 18-93) participated in a task where they were asked to view a series of word-image pairs. After a thirty-minute delay, they completed a surprise three-part memory test inside the fMRI scanner. For all memory trials, they were asked whether the presented word had been studied with an image at encoding (“old” response) or if it had not been seen before (“new” response). In one task, their response was not followed by any specific instruction; the word remained on the screen until it was time for the next trial. In the second, their response was followed by a brief distractor task. In the final task, their response was followed by an explicit instruction to elaborate on their memory for an additional 5 seconds, thinking about as many details as possible.

            Analyses examined age-related changes to recruitment of sensory regions during the post-response portion of the memory trial, where participants either were not given any specific instruction, were asked to do a distractor task, or were asked to elaborate. We found age-related increases in recruitment only when participants were asked to elaborate on additional details of the memory. This finding suggests that older adults were only able to rely on these sensory regions—regions that were spontaneously recruited by young adults to support memory—when provided with this explicit retrieval support.

Follow-up analyses examined how well this recruitment can support better memory in older adults. Although recruitment of sensory regions were not associated with increased vividness ratings, recruitment was associated with increased memory accuracy. Once again, this relation was only apparent when the elaboration instruction was provided. In contrast, recruitment was actually associated with decreased accuracy in the absence of this instruction. These findings suggest that older adults can utilize sensory regions to support visual memory, but may not do so spontaneously. This finding was supported by a behavioral companion study showing greater benefits of the elaboration instruction on older adults’ ability to recall visual details relative to their vividness ratings

            The research described above examined the effects of age in a cross-sectional design where participants of different ages were all tested at the same time. These sorts of designs can inform theories of aging, but do not directly test the aging process within particular individuals, over time. To better understand this process, we conducted an exploratory analysis with 14 participants who completed the elaboration instruction task during two sessions, 8-10 years apart. Comparing recruitment of regions supporting sensory processing at the two test sessions revealed that participants were more likely to show greater post-response recruitment as they aged. This pattern confirmed what had been seen in the cross-sectional designs and supported the theory that this shift was being driven by aging.

Together, these analyses support prior research showing that that older adults are capable of relying on sensory regions during memory retrieval, and suggest that this capability may be dependent on the inclusion of specific instructions to elaborate on the memory in more detail. Future research will examine how different instructions may strengthen or weaken this effect in older adults. In addition to showing that prior reports of global age-related deficits in sensory recruitment may have been exaggerated by research designs, these findings are important because they highlight ways in which future memory tasks can be changed to better support older adults.
